intro: Allium acutangulum var. petraeum, commonly known as the rock garlic or alpine leek, is a perennial plant native to high-altitude regions of Asia. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and small, clustered white or pink flowers. The plant produces bulbous structures that are often used in traditional medicine and cuisine. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to cold, mountainous climates. Due to its unique habitat and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
